Introduction

Physician misconduct is any behavior that violates professional, ethical, or legal standards and can result in disciplinary action from a state medical board, civil charges, and, potentially, criminal charges.  Reporting physician misconduct is essential for protecting patient safety and maintaining public trust.

Types of physician misconduct



Each state has a set of statutes known as the Medical Practice Act, which delineates rules and regulations for the practice of medicine, including what constitutes physician misconduct:



  • Medical negligence & substandard care.
    • Repeated medical errors leading to patient harm.
    • Patient abandonment (ie, terminating care for a patient without providing adequate notice).
    • Prescription of pain medication in excess or without legitimate reason.
  • Sexual misconduct and boundary violations.
    • Sexual assault or harassment of a patient, colleague, or health care team member.
    • Any sexual or romantic relationship with a patient (regardless of consent).
  • Substance use and impairment.
    • Provision of patient care while under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
    • Diversion of prescription medications for personal use.
  • Fraud and financial misconduct.
    • Billing fraud (eg, overbilling, billing for unperformed procedures).
    • Illegal financial relationships (eg, kickbacks for patient referrals).
    • Falsification of credentials (eg, practicing without a medical degree).
  • Discrimination and harassment.
    • Racial or gender-based harassment.
    • Discriminatory practices in patient care (eg, quality of care differing based on patient's weight, age, income level, education).
  • Criminal activity.
    • Illegal behavior, such as drug trafficking or theft.
  • Professional misconduct & ethical violations.
    • Failure to maintain patient confidentiality (violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act [HIPAA]).
    • Acceptance of expensive gifts from patients.
    • Misrepresentation of completion of medical licensing requirements.
  • Research misconduct.
    • Failure to disclose a conflict of interest.
    • Fabrication of data.

Consequences of physician misconduct

State medical board actions



The state medical board investigates complaints of physician misconduct, resulting in either dismissal of the complaint (if there is no evidence of physician misconduct) or a hearing before a disciplinary panel.  If the physician is found to violate the Medical Practice Act, the state medical board may decide to take 1 or more of the following actions:



  • Revocation or temporary suspension of medical license.
  • Restriction of medical license (eg, ineligible to prescribe controlled substances or perform certain procedures).
  • Probation (ie, physician is permitted to practice only under certain conditions for a time).  Examples include requiring enrollment in a physician health program or conducting random urine drug screens.
  • Required completion of additional continuing medical education (eg, 8 hr of ethics).
  • Monetary penalty/fine.

Medical malpractice



Physician misconduct (eg, negligence, providing patient care while inebriated) can result in a civil lawsuit involving medical malpractice liability if the action is not consistent with accepted standards of care and directly causes patient harm (eg, emotional suffering, physical injury, death) (

Duty to report physician misconduct

Self-reporting requirements



State medical boards have varying self-reporting requirements.  Many require self-reporting criminal convictions (eg, felonies, misdemeanors), out-of-state disciplinary actions, and medical malpractice claims within a specific time frame (eg, 30 days).  Failure to do so may result in revocation or suspension of a medical license.

Reporting physician colleagues



Physicians are ethically and legally obligated to report impaired, incompetent, or unethical colleagues to protect patient safety.  Reporting is required when a physician strongly suspects, directly observes, or is informed of (eg, by a patient) a colleague engaging in misconduct.



  • Gather evidence.
    • Document specific incidents (dates, times, locations).
    • Be objective and factual in reporting concerns.
  • Follow institutional policies.
    • If patient safety is in immediate danger, report it to the supervisor on duty.
    • Reporting may involve contacting the hospital ethics office or risk management.
    • Many hospital systems have an anonymous compliance hotline for reporting misconduct.
  • Report to the state medical board.
    • Each state has a medical board that investigates physician misconduct.
    • Reports can often be submitted online, via phone, or in writing.
  • Involve law enforcement if necessary (eg, for criminal activity such as child abuse).

Consequences of failing to report



  • Harm to patients:  Inaction, which may result in patient injury/death.
  • Professional consequences:  State medical board sanctions (eg, loss of license).
  • Legal consequences:  Medical malpractice liability for negligence.
  • Erosion of public trust:  Damaged reputation of the medical profession.

Summary



Physician misconduct is any behavior that violates professional, ethical, or legal standards.  Consequences of misconduct include disciplinary action from a state medical board, civil charges (medical malpractice), and, potentially, criminal charges.  Physicians are ethically and legally obligated to report colleagues engaging in misconduct to protect patient safety and maintain public trust.
